name: Fight The Dragon
description: A COMMUNITY CREATED Hack'n Slash RPG where players can team up and tackle exciting adventures made by other community members in our in-game Adventure Construction Kit - It's DIABLO meets LITTLE BIG PLANET!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP+ Processor: Intel i3+ or equivalent Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: Nvidia 8800, Radeon HD35xx, Intel HD 4000+ DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 500 MB available space Additional Notes: Requires an Xinput compatible gamepad
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7+ Processor: Intel i5+ or equivalent Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: NVidia 560+ or equivalent DirectX: Version 9.0c Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 1 GB available space Additional Notes: Requires an Xinput compatible gamepad

reviews.review_text: Fight the Dragon is a micro ARPG with an action-figure aesthetic and a full-featured level creator dubbed the  Adventure Construction Kit . From the clean and minimal UI to the condensed gameplay loop, Fight the Dragon provides a surprisingly rewarding experience in an adorable and cleverly-shrunken package. Think 10-minute-Torchlight II; heaps of random loot, simple character progression, and tight hack 'n' slash combat. 3 Sprockets has taken the the staples of a genre it clearly adores and compressed them into a shining little diamond.

Simple, fun, old-school and rewarding. Best integration of a level editor into a game I've seen. Can be complex enough for adults or simple enough for kids. My thanks to the devs for adding the simple 'no blood' feature before launch -- something most players never see or use but will gripe about if mentioned, yet it allows me to buy copies for my kids (they don't like the blood, I don't need it and most who gripe about having the option aren't parents). Thanks.

So much fun! This game, while simple, is incredibly well supported by the community. More often than not, the levels you play are community creations, and they are REALLY good. Buy this, even if you aren't used to this kind of game, and enjoy it. It's very easy to get into.

This is the perfect game for when you only have 15-20 minutes to play a game, but you feel like playing an RPG. Most similar games don't really have anything that you can actually accomplish in that timeframe.   Downsides: The game needs difficulty of community generated levels to be voted on by the community. I've already seen several community made levels that were very likely impossible marked as 'easy'. I'm guessing this is done by trolls, but allowing people to just vote on how hard they thought the level was would alleviate that issue.

This is an incredible game. The mechanics are fast-working, and the game has no lag. The lever creator software is simple to use, but also allows for an incredible amount of freedom. It is slightly tedious, but the adventures come out incrediblty, as long as you've thought them through. The hack-n-slash adventure mechanics are fun to play, and there is always a challanging level to play.With amazing skins and graphics, and an overall amazing playstyle, this game has it all. Two thumbs up!

The dungeon creater is very easy to use and you can let you imagination run wild while ♥♥♥♥ off other players but loving you at the same time lol. Another game that offers an addictive building mode, I played Fight the Dragon pretty heavily when I first got it. I became obsessed with the dungeon creator mode. I had even made the top 100 list at some point, which was pretty cool. After I created my King George dungeon, I lost interest. That's par for the course with me, though, and not a complaint about the game. I play obsessively until I've had enough, then break for a while. But if you like games with creative modes, then you'll probably enjoy Fight the Dragon.  The game has more to offer than just the creative mode, but that's what I was there for. :)
Pretty good game. allot of fun. If you are a rpg fan, wanna make you own dungeons and play a dungeon crawler. Buy it.

This game is awesome, 9/10 I recommend it to anyone who enjoys playing games. Matter of fact I bought a second copy for a friend because its just that good. If you enjoy dungeon crawlers like Diablo or Torchlight, this might be right up your alley. I really enjoy dungeon crawlers, but quickly grow tired of repetative levels. The customization via the Workshop really offers a level of flexibility such that the community itself helps the game to evolve.   Though there is currently not an overwhelming amount of content available, this game offers incredible potential, and is already enjoyable. It would be really nice to see a larger variety of classes, but given the price, I certainly cannot complain.

Incredibly fun and surprisingly challenging! Best game I've played in a long while. 10/10 Think Diablo style RPG at the core but with more user flexibility. This game has massive potential and is already among one of my all time favorites. The devs are quite active with the community and still have many plans on adding even more to the game. If you're on the fence about whether or not to get the game then just wait for a sale and pick it up asap. It's definitely worth it.

I am looking forward to additional content being added though as it has an OK amount of content to be fun, but it needs more for variety. The main negative I would pose is the AI is a bit clunky at times and multiplayer triggers seem to have issues.

I got this for the ACK (adventure creation kit?) and it delivers. Yeah, its kid-like graphics and some things simply do not do what you'd expect, but the core is rock solid. Before ever actually playing, I spent 8 hours building a campaign, then finally got around to playing the game. The inventory, loot, xp, loot shrine - 'store' basically, did NOT leave a lot to be desired. Despite the simplicity, the mechanics are satisfying. This game is a great example of how a non-AAA looking game can blow you away. Heck, could this be the next Minecraft? We'll see.

This is a great hack and slash RPG with 4 classes, each with thier own weapons. I've played for a bit and I really enjoy it! There are lots of different dungeons and maps that you can play on that is all community generated, and a place where you can make your own. There is an option to search for different maps as well. I always play it with friends. I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes a good RPG and wants to play games with thier friends. The dragon itself is hard for me to beat though.

Very enjoyable if a bit unpolished. Could use some work on the inventory and a more complete/clearer tutorial.

Despite all of its flaws, this is still one of my favorite games to play with my friends. There is so much fun to be had just exploring and plundering the various missions and dungeons that people have made for this game, ranging from open-world style exploration minions to dungeon crawling and boss rushes. The level editor is simple and easy to use, with the ability to build story into them with NPCs and whatnot giving the game ridiculous longevity.  The game isn't perfect, though. The UI takes a little bit of getting used to, and the combat is pretty lacklustre. Not to mention the game's survival is dependent on the support of its player base.  TL;DR version:  Pros: - Lots of variety in levels - Great to play with friends - Finding new loot is addictive and exciting - Good variety in the different classes  Cons: - Combat leaves a bit to be desired - Can't easily search for specific levels to play with friends

Very, very good game :)

There's a lot to like about this game - unlimited adventures, fun combat, nice graphics, and a strong developer presence in the forums. It's not perfect though. Community made maps are hit or miss. There's a ton of great content out there, but unfortunately you'll need to wade through quite a bit of clunkers to get to them.   As a single player game, it has a limited life span since each map is pretty much the same monsters/puzzles/traps just in different orders. Once you are able to get multiplayer working for more than 5 minutes, it becomes extremely fun again. I'm not sure if the problem lies with me or the servers, but there were plenty of frustrating moments with either disconnects or just plain not being able to connect at all. The gameplay makes those frustrations worth it though, but beware problems do exist.  Bottom line, this game is definitely worth full price even with the drawbacks, but as always, it's best to wait for a sale.

If you want something different, there are hundreds of levels that you can choose from, you can even pick the same level you have played before, I have not experienced any problems with glitches, lag, or problems connecting to friends. I hope to see a healer and a archer with the new updates to come. If you have a little bit of money left in your steam wallet, you must buy this game, even if you are just by yourself playing it, you will have a blast playing Fight the Dragon.

There is an indescribable charm about this game that I just can't get over. I picked it up during the Summer Sale because it was less than three bucks. My expectations going in were for an hour-or-two-throwaway, barely finished product.  What I got instead has enthralled me so much the past two days. I can play for five minutes or get lost in a two-hour binge. The maps are long enough to feel detailed but short enough to complete in one sitting. Combat can get repetitive but with new and better loot dropping here and there, from enemies and chests, I didn't really care; it's good, plain fun. There are four classes with individual spells and special abilities - a fighter, fire mage, ice mage and rogue - but I've only played as an 'Ice Wizard' up to this point without losing any interest or even gaining a desire to try other classes. I'm having too much fun with this one.  There's also a map/adventure/campaign editor where you can create your own landscapes, buildings, villages, etc. etc. You can also script NPCs to talk to the player when he approaches as well as decorate your worlds with trees, rocks, fountains, bookshelves, beds, chairs... You name it. With a touch of detail here and there, worlds come alive. The editor has some rudimentary logic chains and pressure pads so that you can create some quite interesting and complex puzzles, though I'll admit, I haven't delved into that area quite yet.  Buy this game. You will not regret it. I haven't had this much fun playing a game in who knows how long.

The game model functions very well - controls, stats, loot, combat (for the most part), and co-op. The premise of the game is to adventure in community-created campaigns, finding keys, unraveling small plots, looting better items, and making your way to fighting the dragon by collecting Dragon Scrolls. It's almost like Shadowrun Returns, but without the developer-created campaign. There are some REALLY good adventures to go on by the community.  However, it's like finding needles in a haystack - the majority of GREAT community-created scenarios are far and few between. Many fall short between amateur DMs and wannabe writers akin to middle school English class. 75% of the adventures you will partake in often have glaring issues like loot balancing, confusing or short level design, awful dialogue and spelling mistakes and more. It seems like anyone can create a dungeon with 5 rooms, 50 potions, tons of easy enemies and enough loot to make the game not much fun.  This game is AMAZING for DM's and really shines in the way of quick pick-up and random co-op play. It falls short in the way that the majority of the content is shallow or just bad. If you dig hard enough, you'll find gold though.

Pros:   Making the maps is a lot of fun (although I would like more options.)  Cons:   Most of the maps the community makes are awful and it's not easy to find good ones.     The combat is mind numbingly boring.

As a game I can not recommend this. It sounds good, and there are tons of maps.  But: it feels more like a sandbox-title.... with a bad camera, clumsy controls and odd hit/collision-detection. And no storyline, just 'random' maps, with some Steam-achievements thrown in. Yet somehow not rewarding at all, as there is no soul to it. I find it hard to find any feelings for that title. It is just: Meh! (in a bad way)  However, one might find it entertaining for some hours running around and killing every creature on any of the (endless) maps. If you are into grinding, keeping a clean and sorted inventory (selling the bad stuff) .... this 'game' provides plenty of that - with bad camera, clumsy controls and odd hit/collision-detection.  PS: Did I mention the camera?!

This game gets boring after a while. There's a few hillarious bugs in the game that made me laugh my head off, but that's basically the best part. There are some very challenging and fun dungeons, but most of them are easy as heck, even though they shouldn't be. Why? Crossbows. You basically just need a crossbow and some decent juking strats and kiting strats if things get out of hand, because crossbows can stun enemies. They're basically unbalanced. Also, Fighting the Dragon is kinda boring. It has 4 basic moves that you can all dodge easily except for one of them, and 2 op abilities that can half shot you at level 15ish that you can dodge easily. There's also a bug that you can get while fighting the dragon, maybe in dungeons too. If you stand still and just use basic attacks, the dragon will keep attacking you until you get down to 1 hp. Then, for some reason, the game shows the dragon doing damage, but it actually doesn't and you become virtually immortal unless you use a heavy attack, special move, or you do a dodge roll. It's fun for the first 15 hours, then it gets boring.

Note: Reason to why I have so few hours into the game will be answered also in the review.   Firstly the game goes the easy ( read: lazy ) route of block-graphics ( Minecraft-inspired ). If you hate it then I think this game is not for you. I personally don't like it, but can handle it if the game is good.  This seems like a nice concept: Hack-n-Slash game with community content and custom dungeons and LOOTING!!!! So what we look for in this game is how fun it is to LOOT, how fun the classes and their development is and how good the combat feels. Let's see how it fares. In those 3 aspects.  Looting in this game seemed quite decent. I mean you get frequent chests, you get monster drops and 'higher-value' chests and also something like a 'boss'-drops. The system where you can 'donate' junk and gold to shrine to 'pray' for random good items for various slots is also a nice gamble and adds to all of the Gearing up aspect of an Hack-n-Slash.  The combat is where the game falls flat and by a huge margin. By no means is combat any fun. The hit detection is abysmal. I feel this game has worse or more difficult combat than Dark Souls for PC and that game aims to be difficult and challenging. Half the time you will be missing the enemy because you're not facing them, that's okay... half of the time when you are facing the enemy you still won't hit it, because your cursor is slightly off! Now even with everything angled right the hit-boxes are drunk and sway around the actual model.   The classes... You have 4 classes ( 2 mages, a warrior and a semi-warrior )... All of whom mostly swing their prefered weapon, at least at the early levels. Now I want you to pick ANY 4 heroes/champions/classes from an MOBA game and imagine having a GRINDING RPG game built around them... you have 4 abilities that hardly ever improve or feel different for all of the gear grinding and loot farming. I said 4? Yes that is if you play with each and seperate one, but mostly you'll be stuck with ONE.  I might have a bit biased oppinion, but that's what this god-awful combat system got me to. I have few reviews and generally prefer to write pleasant and good ones about games I like, but for me to write a negative one, the game seriously must SUCK.   I understand that the game is popular amongst some of you people, but so is Minecraft... and hell if I knew why..
only fun part is the character creation. the rest of the game is just clunky and Not Very Fun™

I wanted to like this and was drawn in by the positive reviews. Sadly, it feels VERY casual and easy, bland and boring; maybe good for younger players. It was only tolerable for about 1 hour and then I wasn't having fun. Don't expect any class depth. Character movement is slow and unfulfilling. There is virtually no story. The player model looks like a cheesy cross between a Mii and a Lego guy. Ultimately, there is nothing to draw you in and I found very little reason to keep playing. Trust me when I say that the reviews here on Steam make it sound much more fun than it is. I'd recommend passing for now unless you're in it for the level editing or something.

We played for a while, intrigued by the interesting concept, but were really let down by the gameplay itself. We couldn't help but find it an incredibly boring game which requires no cooperation at all. The fights are incredibly easy and uninvolving, the riddles are rather bland and not even the best-rated community map was interesting apart from looking pretty good. This game had a lot of potential and when I saw it during a sale I thought why not. I bought the 4-pack for me and my friends for about 8 USD, and found the fighting aspect of it was pretty terrible. I have not tried the building aspect of it and may try to just to see what it is like but the battle mechanics are just too easy. The controls are mediocre and it just feels like you're playing a game for children. I will say there are a few things that I can give for it is the art style of the environment. It looks really nice and the textures for the levels made by people look finished and nice. But the character models seem a bit stolen from Roblox. Lastly, if you have a friend or more playing with you the game will be so increasingly easy that you will not die.
This game is funny the two fist hours. After, it's boring and very repetitive.

I am posting this 'review' after investing almost 8 hours of gameplay over two weeks. I don't think that's enough time to call this a propper review, so let's call it a first impressions. If I make it past 16 hours within the next two weeks, I'll review my review and fix anything I may have gotten wrong.  This is a game that feels like it should be in early access instead of full release. I do hope that it improves, but I cannot reccomend this game in its current state.  But before I put in a wall of text about how it sucks, first I'll go over what this game does right:  1) Map Editor. Any game with an in-buillt map editor gets brownie points from me, I love creating custom content (even though I suck at it). This editor is clunky and un-intuitive (you can tell it was designed with controllers in mind), but it exists so I'm happy.  2) Community created content. You mean there's constantly new stuff and I don't have to wait on the devs to make it? sweet.  3) It's pretty. The aesthetic is simplistic, but nice. The cartoonish feel works well with high-res textures on low-poly models.  4) It hasn't crashed yet, nor have I experienced any noticable frame-drops (running a AMD FX-4170 / GTX550ti if that helps anyone).  That's about it. Now to complaining!  1) Controls are extremely clunky. The delay between pressing the attack buttons, performing the animation, and being able to do something else (such as move) is waaaaaaaaay too long and has resulted in many bulshit deahts. I can tell that the issue is a lack of animation cancelling (look at Diablo3, which this game claims to partially inspiried by, it feels great because everything responds immediatly).  2) You can't change attack directions between strikes. This could just be part of 1, but it's aggrivating enough to warrent it's own spot)  3) Hitboxes don't match up with attack animations. Need I say more?  4) The auto-targetting system frequently can't find on-screen targets. Prime example is The Dragon, which makes wands (hitscan projectile weapon) completely useless because it relies entirely on the auto-targetting system to automaticcly hit things then the attack button is pressed. Speaking of auto-targetting, you can't aim things yourself, it just goes in the direction you're facing (unless the auto-target finds something, which as I said is unreliable).  5) This might just be a problem with inexperienced map makers, but several of the levels can be 'broken' by getting on top of the outside wall (which I'm certain you're not supposed to be able to do) to find the exit in seconds in a level that should take half an hour.  6) Lack of variety in class builds. So I a basic attack that varies on weapon, a secondary attack that varies whether that weapon is one handed or two handed, and four class abilities that never change (you just unlock them as you progress). Come on. Diablo 2 had 30 class skills PER CLASS (granted several were passives), and it came out in what year? I know comparing an indie dev to blizzard isn't fair, but they brought it upon themselves when the description said it's like diablo meets little big planet. That set some high expectations.   I'm still playing it though so I guess it's fun.

So, me and my FOUR year old picked it up (I needed something decently 'kid-friendly' with LOCAL Coop and Controller support).  TL;DR: Not 100% Coop. Very misleading. As you cannot fight the dragon with anyone else.  Pros: Loot system, easy combat system, plenty of adventures, there's a dragon you can chip away at for awhile  Cons: The too easy combat system, TOO many crappy/unbalanced (especially some of the 'easy') adventures, you can't take anyone with you to fight the dragon. Gold has no use at all other than donating (so why even bother having in the game? Not very meaningful gameplay there)    I really think that if they just had some other use for the gold, and allowed coop for the dragon, and cleaned up the combat system, this would be an easy 90%+/Gold game if everything had some meaning. Otherwise, me and my four year old enjoy running around pointlessly and killing things together...  Good luck on Pacman, hope that you learn from your mistakes on this one.

I played Fight the Dragon last night with a friend, and I don't really have any desire to play it again. I love dungeon crawlers (huge fan of the Diablos and Torchlights). I found this game to be quite glitchy (random locking of items, spell/ability book on the side of the house not available, not being able to switch inputs even after re-loading the game), and so did my friend. We didn't play the campaign, we just went for reward runs, and while most of the levels were great in concept, the designs in terms of gameplay were at times frustrating (like being able to get to a water area past a cliff but no way to get back, or killing a boss that opens a door on a timer, not making it in time, and the only option was to quit the level rather than try again). I got the humour of things like the item names and the NPC dialogues, but I found that it grew tiresome after a few hours. Maybe if there wasn't the frustration of the glitches, that might not have been the case.  I really like the concept, and I certainly see why it was supported. But in actual gameplay, it just didn't speak to me personally. Based on the reviews, it obviously spoke to others, though. :-)
